FacilityName: City of Beaumont Water Reclamation Plant

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Chlorine Institute, Compressed Gas Association, Texas Administrative Code

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description

The City of Beaumont Water Reclamation Plant went into operation in 1955. It serves a population of 120,000 people and has an average daily flow of 22 million gallons of wastewater per day. The facility is a high rate continuous recirculation two stage trickling filter design followed by polishing ponds, chlorination and advanced treatment by a constructed wetland. The City uses from 150 pounds to 2000 pounds of chlorine per day to disinfect the treated wastewater. Up to 15 one-ton chlorine containers (30,000 pounds) are stored on site under a canopy to protect them from sunlight.  This quantity is above the threshold quantity established by the Environmental Protection Agency, and the Plant is therefore subject to the requirements of the Risk Management Program.

Safety features for the chlorination system include windows, an exhaust fan, and a leak detector in the chlorine building, and a safety shower, eyewash station, and SCBA located outside the chlorine building. A leak detector is also mounted outside the chlorine building near the one ton containers. The leak detectors have both visual and audible alarm signals when a dangerous level of chlorine gas is present.  No accidental releases of chlorine meeting the requirements of the five year accident history, as defined in the Risk Management program regulations, have ever occurred at the facility.

Offsite Consequence Analysis

The off-site consequences of a potential accidental release of chlorine at the Water Reclamation Plant were assessed in accordance with requirements established in 40 Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68.  SLAB Atmospheric Dispersion Model, an EPA-recognized computer modeling program, was used to model a worst case release scenario and an alternative release scenario.  

The worst case scenario is a model of a chlorine release under specific conditions established by EPA, including release volume, duration, and weather conditions. Active safety systems in place at t

he Plant that are designed to minimize the effects of a chlorine release cannot be considered in the worst case scenario.  

The worst case release scenario is required to assume the release in a ten minute period of the entire contents of the largest vessel of the regulated chemical onsite, which for the Plant is a one-ton chlorine container.  Meteorological conditions required by EPA rules are assumed for the release.  The toxic endpoint for the worst case release scenario is estimated to reach a point beyond the boundary of the facility. Since this facility is located in a populated area, the chlorine vapor would reach offsite endpoints and nearby public receptors.  No sensitive environmental  receptors are located within the release area.

The alternative release scenario represents the results more likely to occur in the event of a chlorine release at the Plant.  Active safety systems at the Plant are considered for the alternative release scenario. Average weather conditions at the facility are used for this release scenario, as recommended by EPA regulations.

Failure of a pipe in the chlorine feed system is assumed for the chlorine alternative release scenario.  While the toxic endpoint for the chlorine alternative release scenario is estimated to reach a point beyond the facility boundary, no public receptors or sensitive environmental receptors designated by EPA are affected by this release scenario.


Prevention Program

The Water Reclamation Plant is subject to Prevention Program 2 of the Risk Management Program.  In accordance with the requirements of Program 2, the Plant maintains specifications for the equipment associated with the chlorine feed system and has documented the codes and standards adhered to in designing, constructing, and operating the system.  The safe operating ranges for the chlorine system are documented, and it is operated within these safe ranges.

A hazard review has been conducted for the chlorine system and identified action it

ems were completed by December 31, 2002.  When a major process change is made to the system, there are procedures in place to conduct a hazard review.  Otherwise, a hazard review is conducted every five years.

Written procedures for the operation and maintenance of the chlorine system are also in place for the Plant.  Procedures are reviewed and updated periodically by facility personnel and whenever a major process change occurs.

Plant operators receive training in the operation of the chlorine system through classes and on-the-job instruction.  Competency is determined through supervisor observation, operator demonstration of activities, and written and oral tests.  Operators receive refresher training at least every three years, or more often as necessary.  Only qualified operators operate the chlorine system.

A team of City personnel conducts a compliance audit of the facility operations and procedures once every three years and whenever a major process modification is made.  A compliance audit checklist has been developed based on American Water Works Association recommendations.  A system to correct any deficiency discovered during the compliance audit is in place.

In the event of an accidental release, or a situation that could lead to an accidental release, there are procedures in place to investigate such incidents, develop findings and recommendations for corrective action, and implement the recommendations.

Plant personnel are trained to notify emergency personnel in the event of a significant chlorine leak.  In the unlikely event a chlorine release requiring the assistance of offsite emergency response personnel occurs, the City of Beaumont Fire Department is responsible for responding to the accident, coordinating the emergency response effort, and notifying potentially affected areas in the surrounding community.
